posts.cooked:
While not completely related to frc, i thought i would ask here since im using some frc motor controllers for my personal project. Is it possible to, on the old SPARK motor controllers, daisy chain together the power and ground wires of the pwm-y signal wire instead of feeding them each individually? Id like to clean up how many wires i have to run to the spark motor controllers. image 4032×3024 3.27 MB

image 4032×3024 3.27 MB

image 4032×3024 3.27 MB

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked: Try disconnecting the power wire altogether; most FRC motor controllers don’t even need it.

Thanks so much you were right the 5v input isn’t necessary.

MetabolicCloth:

Yes you can

So there’s no issue with ground being relative with having the ground inputs for the pwm in “series” all daisy chained rather than in parallel from the same source?

posts.name: Ken Pontbriant
posts.cooked: There is a bit of a “gotcha” in a series connection of the PWM inputs. If I remember correctly, the input of those motor controllers is an optical isolator used specifically to avoid ground reference issues. The infrared LED in those isolators has a forward voltage drop of somewhere around 1.5 volts. If you connect more than 2 in series I don’t think they will see sufficient current to operate with a 5V input signal.

Hmm, but as usbcd36 pointed out, the SPARK motor controllers don’t actually need the 5V input from the PWM to function. I think the ground is serving as a reference point for High and Low in the PWM signal, so I’m thinking the small amount of current drawn from the PWM could change the reference for the other motor controllers, possibly leading to issues when I run them. I think I might just keep four separate ground wires. The ability to remove of the 5V wires is useful though haha.

posts.name: Ken Pontbriant
posts.cooked: The PWM signal has a 5V amplitude.
Oops haha i see now thank you for your help.

posts.name: Davo
posts.cooked: To add to this, the roboRIO PWM power pins run at 6V.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: A Buch of motor controllers in a plastic box with silica gel; Are you making a submarine?

posts.name: kgzak
posts.cooked:
The last page of the spark user manual has a schematic.

1013.26 KB

The 5v isn’t needed at all, the gnd is used in the opto-isolator. You are probably fine using the same ground wire for each controller.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
The term “series” has a specific meaning in electronics and is not appropriate in this application.

It should be acceptable to use a single wire for the return connection, daisy-chained from one motor controller to the next. The currents are not very high so any voltage drop effects will be insignificant.

Wow, you got surprisingly close based just on the plastic box and silica gel. Sadly, if you’ve ever tried making an ROV, you would find that a plastic box and silica gel tend to be nowhere near good enough for underwater use . This is rather for an unmanned ocean surface vessel; Just has to be protected from splashing.

philso:

The term “series” has a specific meaning in electronics and is not appropriate in this application.

yeah I knew it wasn’t right but I wasn’t sure how to best get the idea across which is why I put it in quotes.

Im not sure if it would actually be insiginificant. Correct me if im wrong but from the schematic kgzak linked above, OPTO-ISO-TLP118 is whats used.

613.43 KB

The TLP118 has a typical forward voltage of 1.61 volts, so would it not end up causing issues with the signal? It is probably best to just run them separately no?

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: Ah I should have known based on the background. Too wide for a ROV

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
As I stated before, you should be okay running just one wire to act as the return for the inputs for all 4 of the Spark motor controllers.

The schematic for the Spark motor controller shows that it has a 150 Ohm resistor in series with the anode of the LED in the photocoupler. A 5 V signal applied to the input pin would cause a current of about 23 mA to flow. Connecting the returns for 4 Sparks would result in a total current of less than 100 mA. This should not cause enough voltage drop through the small wires and connectors to be significant. I have designed (and worked on) many circuit boards with this sort of arrangement and not had any issues.
